metadata.title: Robinson R22
aws::graph::propositions: Robinson R22 Startup and Autorotation System
For startup, the engine is started with the belts loose in the Robinson R22.
Loose belts allow the engine to run without spinning the rotor system in the Robinson R22.
Immediately after engine start, the pilot closes the clutch switch located in the cockpit.
The closed clutch switch powers the actuator in the Robinson R22.
The actuator slowly raises the upper sheave to flight position.
The raised upper sheave tightens the belts in the Robinson R22.
The actuator is controlled by pressure-sensing column springs after initial engagement.
Pressure-sensing column springs automatically maintain proper belt tension during flight.
Automatic tension maintenance occurs as the belts wear and stretch.
The shaft on which the upper sheave is mounted drives both the main and tail rotors.
The main gear box delivers power to the main rotor shaft through a set of spiral bevel gears.
The spiral bevel gears in the main gear box are splash-lubricated.
A one-way sprag clutch is built into the center of the upper sheave.
The sprag clutch allows the rotor system to continue to rotate in the event of engine failure.
Continued rotor rotation allows the Robinson R22 to enter autorotation.
Autorotation allows the Robinson R22 to land in a controlled manner during engine failure.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 has very little mass.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 has very little inertia.
Autorotation in a Robinson R22 requires careful execution to assure a successful outcome.
Autorotation in a Robinson R22 requires proper execution to assure a successful outcome.

statements.value: For startup, the engine is started with the belts loose in the Robinson R22.
Loose belts allow the engine to run without spinning the rotor system in the Robinson R22.

The closed clutch switch powers the actuator in the Robinson R22.

Automatic tension maintenance occurs as the belts wear and stretch.

The spiral bevel gears in the main gear box are splash-lubricated.
A one-way sprag clutch is built into the center of the upper sheave.
The sprag clutch allows the rotor system to continue to rotate in the event of engine failure.
Continued rotor rotation allows the Robinson R22 to enter autorotation.

Autorotation in a Robinson R22 requires careful execution to assure a successful outcome.
Autorotation in a Robinson R22 requires proper execution to assure a successful outcome.

text:
For startup, the engine is started with the belts loose, allowing the engine to run without spinning the rotor system.  Immediately after engine start, the clutch switch located in the cockpit is closed by the pilot, powering the actuator to slowly raise the upper sheave to flight position, which tightens the belts.  The actuator is thereafter controlled by pressure-sensing column springs, automatically maintaining proper belt tension during flight as the belts wear and stretch. The shaft on which the upper sheave is mounted drives both the main and tail rotors; the main gear box delivers power to the main rotor shaft through a set of splash-lubricated spiral bevel gears.
A one-way sprag clutch is built into the center of the upper sheave to allow the rotor system to continue to rotate in the event of engine failure, allowing the R22 to enter autorotation and land in a controlled manner.  Because the main rotor has very little mass and inertia, autorotation in an R22 requires careful and proper execution to assure a successful outcome.
